article.headline: âFortniteâ maker accuses Apple, Google of illegal monopolistic practices in tech battle royale
article.body: The maker of âFortniteâ has launched a Battle Royale against Apple Inc. and Alphabet Inc., filing lawsuits against the two tech giants that claim they illegally exploit a monopoly on app and in-app purchases. Epic Games filed legal papers against Apple AAPL, +1.74% Â and Alphabetâs GOOGL, +1.82% Â GOOG, +1.97% Â Google after the two tech giants booted the companyâs hit game âFortniteâ out of their app stores Thursday, after Epic publicly announced an offer for players to receive a discount on in-game purchases if they paid Epic directly. Apple and Google take up to 30% of all purchases in their app stores, and Appleâs approach to its app ecosystem has recently faced antitrust heat from the U.S. government. In the first lawsuit filed Thursday, against Apple, Epic said it would seek âto end Appleâs unfair and anticompetitive actions that Apple undertakes to unlawfully maintain its monopoly.â The game maker came prepared for a fight, debuting a video that spoofs Appleâs classic 1984 advertisement, which urged customers to oppose conformity and prevent International Business Machines Inc. IBM, -2.81% Â from dominating the computer market. Back then, Apple warned that without a change, the year 1984 could mirror George Orwellâs dystopian â1984â novel; Epic Games cautions in its ad that 2020 could come to embody â1984â as well. div.youtube { height:0; position:relative; padding-bottom:56.25%; } div.youtube > iframe { position: absolute; left: 0; top: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; } Apple is worth nearly $2 trillion thanks to the money it collects from the iPhone and the apps and services that are delivered through it. Fortnite had racked up $1 billion in player spending on Apple iOS devices alone through mid-May, according to mobile-app research company Sensor Tower, which would suggest Apple received hundreds of millions of dollars from the hit videogame. For more: Apple and Facebook could be most vulnerable among the antitrust suspects Evercore ISI analyst Amit Daryanani said in a note to clients late Thursday that Apple collects an estimated $30 million monthly from Fortnite. The company generated $13.2 billion last quarter in revenue for its services segment, which includes the App Store. He expects the legal battle to be âa multi-year process that is appealed at every level of the U.S. court system.â Epic has long tried to avoid paying such fees, previously selling an Android app through its own game store to avoid Androidâs Play Store. Epic eventually did put âFortniteâ on the Play Store, but Google booted it late Thursday for the same reason as Apple, and Epic filed a similar lawsuit later in the evening. âGoogle has eliminated competition in the distribution of Android apps using myriad contractual and technical barriers,â Epic said in making a similar legal argument that it did about Appleâs control of the iOS ecosystem. Those with Android devices will still be able to play the game by downloading it through Epicâs own app store, but they wonât be able to play through the official store offered by Google âbecause it violates our policies,â according to an emailed statement from Google. See also: âFortniteâ spurned Android, then Google found a major security flaw in its app Epic says on its website that players whoâve already downloaded âFortniteâ to their Apple mobile devices âshould have no issues continuing to play Chapter 2 - Season 3âs 13.40 update.â Once the new season begins, Epic expects that players will be able to play the older content but not access new material. An Apple spokesperson said in a statement that Epic Games introduced the feature without the companyâs approval and did so âwith the express intent of violating the App Store guidelines regarding in-app payments.â The statement also said that Apple will âmake every effort to work with Epic to resolve these violations so they can return âFortniteâ to the App Store.â An Epic spokeswoman confirmed the suit in an email to MarketWatch. As part of its blitz against Apple, the company has launched a page on its website with the tagline â#FreeFortniteâ that tells customers to use that hashtag in support of Epic by engaging with the App Storeâs official Twitter account. The hashtag was trending on Twitter within an hour of the siteâs launch. Appleâs fee policies around the App Store have come under increased scrutiny from both developers and regulators recently. Big developers including Spotify Technology SA SPOT, +0.08% Â have looked for ways to avoid paying Apple a cut of subscription fees, and the developers of Hey, a new email app, publicly battled with Apple in June after the email service rolled out its app without an option to buy subscriptions from within the app. Apple and Heyâs developers eventually reached a compromise. Regulators and lawmakers in the U.S. and Europe have also questioned the companyâs App Store policies and whether they stifle competition. Epic argues in its complaint that Apple âharms app developersâ relationship with their customersâ through its mandatory involvement in all transactions since customers âoften blame Epicâ for problems related to payments. âIn addition, Apple is able to obtain information concerning Epicâs transactions with its own customers, even when Epic and its own customers would prefer not to share their information with Apple,â the complaint said. Apple shares rose 1.8% Thursday and have gained more than 50% in the past three months as the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% Â , which counts Apple as a component, has added 20%. Shares declined 0.1% in after-hours trading. Alphabetâs Class A shares rose 0.7% in after-hours trading, and are up 12% over the past three months.
